comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: We shouldn't raise this kind of issue in manual reviews since we have Sonar in place, anyway in terms of logic this method doesn't have so much (it's just a query) and most part of the lines are to call TA methods to retrieve the columns names due to TA persistence framework, instead of creating variables to columns names I could call those methods directly in query but I think this way would make the readability worse. I'll drop this one.

comments.author: Gil Matias

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Could we not just put this all in the return? _return partyManager == null ? PartyFactory.getPartyManager() :partyManager;_

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: No because if we do like that, the partyManager variable will never be set with PartyFactory.getPartyManager() which means that PartyFactory.getPartyManager() will always be called to retrieve the partyManager object, basically we want to have a Singleton approach here.

comments.author: Jose Martinez
comments.comment: There is only one call to getPartyManager

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Yes, this call is in getDecisionDaysBalanceDeductionSum() but you must consider that getDecisionDaysBalanceDeductionSum() will be called many times by another methods which makes this getPartyManager() valid and efficient (singleton approach).

reviewTimeLines.summary: FAB-3859: Set availability status

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Why a lot of transactions in the same method? Can't you do everything in one transaction?

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment:
I've post the same comment in this review:
http://iedev317.development.fineos.com/reviewboard/r/71789/#comment42809
In this screen we update data and query than right after, so we noted that if we put all in one transaction the query right after the update doesn't get the updated data, this can be something related to some configuration from fineos persistence framework (but not sure).

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment:
Possibly move this logic in separate method, more to simplify the already large setDecisionDayStatus method and help simplfy the testing process
To avoid magic number issues could create a constant for 0

comments.comment: Same comment as aboce re: rename

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Same comment as before re: rename

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Same comment as before re: rename

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Can you refactor all these Longs to TimeDecisionStatus? If the map is to hold only values from this enum, will be easier to hold the enum instance and more readable.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Do we actually even need the map for this? The count doesnt seem to matter, its the presence or absence of the various status that seems to be important. Can we not just use a HashSet<TaEnum<TimeDecisionStatus>> instead then, and check set.contains() rather than maintaining a count for each status?!!

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: I've refactored the code completely, I put a query to do the job (no manual counting anymore). Tks for that.

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Can you import the constants from TimeDecisionStatus and remove the classifier to clear more the reading of the code? Hint: CTRL+Shift+M in Eclipse.

comments.author: Sergio Torres
comments.comment: Shouldn't this considerer a 0 when it's null and initialize with the increment?

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
A method should do one thing. This method is doing too much,as it calculating the value to set AND setting it. It should be passed the new status to set, not the map.
Again, I think the logic to get the status should live on a new class for the counter, so it would be
setAvailabilityStatus(counter.getAvailabilityStatus())

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
I think we could do a bit of OOO design here. Can we extract this map to be its own class, with methods for manipulation of same?
A class shuold do one thing. IMO this warrants a class called TimeDecisionStatusCounter, which creates this map as part of its constructor.
If not diong about, then rename this method to createEmptyTimeDecisionStatusCountMap, as its not clear what it does currently.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Consider using Map<TaEnum<TimeDecisionStatus>, AtomicInteger>, as this allows map.get(key).increment(), rather than having to get, increment, and put (as well as extra autoboxing required to convert result of ++count from int into Integer.

comments.author: Sergio Torres
comments.comment: update the javadoc according with the actual parameter

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: IMO this should live on the new map class

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Use GenericUncheckedException, this is handled by TA. We dont throw raw runtime excetption like this normally
No test for this scenario

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment:
Use the constansts in AbsenceSQLUtils and DBUtilities; Use import static for these constants.
Looking for this, seems that you're doing some SQL like this:
SELECT bla FROM DecisionDays INNER JOIN SelectedLeavePlan on conditionsForSelectedLeavePlan GROUP BY bla
This is a very bad way to do SQL. You should invert the tables in the SQL because you should always reduce the scope of the data. The way you're doing you are reading all the lines from DecisionDays table to match the common with SelectedLP and then filter by the second one.
I Expect that DecisionDays will be a monster in the future, so don't do an Open SQL to this table.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: I'll leave the query as is. Inverting the table doesn't make any different (there is no full scan here), the query plan for both queries (mine and your suggestion) are the same and they have the exactly same cost.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Accordingly to DBA Team, there are no performance concerns about the query as is http://jira/browse/FDT-166. I'll drop this but later we can create a jira to test absence queries against massive volume databases in Fineos.

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: In a Join the clauses for the joined table should go to the ON clause instead of WHERE, either by increasing readability and improving performance.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: This doesn't improve any performance, like above, same query plan and cost. About readability I have the opposite opinion: we should restrict/filter the query using WHERE clause and the ON in JOIN is for declaring the connections between the tables (not filtering)

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Same comment as above http://jira/browse/FDT-166.

comments.author: Killian Farrell
comments.comment: DButils for on and inner join

comments.author: Killian Farrell
comments.comment: Why are we not using DButilities?
